title: tutorial
text:
In this project we aim to visualize the trends of the most frequently used babynames from 1880 to 2017 in the United States. We do this by:
- Understanding the different columns of the data set - Find the top 10 most frequently used baby names in the data for: - girls - boys - Plot the yearly trend of the top 10 baby names
![](https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2016/10/02/06/27/baby-1709013_1280.jpg){fig-align=“right”width=400}


For this analysis we’ll use the penguins dataset from palmerpenguins
First load the packages

library(tidyverse)
library(ggthemes)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(gt)


glimpse(penguins)

title: tutorial
text:
For this analysis we’ll use the penguins dataset from palmerpenguins
First load the packages

library(tidyverse)
library(ggthemes)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(gt)


glimpse(penguins)

title: analysis
text:
library(babynames)
library(knitr)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
library(pheatmap)

The first ten lines of the babynames dataset looks like:

head(babynames) |> kable()




year
sex
name
n
prop




1880
F
Mary
7065
0.0723836


1880
F
Anna
2604
0.0266790


1880
F
Emma
2003
0.0205215


1880
F
Elizabeth
1939
0.0198658


1880
F
Minnie
1746
0.0178884


1880
F
Margaret
1578
0.0161672





Here, I’ve created two functions that do the following:

get_most_frequent: Gets the most frequent babynames over a time-period.
plot_top: from the output of get_most_frequent. Plot the top n most popular names.


Code
get_most_frequent <- function(babynames, select_sex, from = 1950) {
  most_freq <- babynames |>
    filter(sex == select_sex, year > from) |>
    group_by(name) |>
    summarise(average = mean(prop)) |>
    arrange(desc(average))

  return(list(
    babynames = babynames,
    most_frequent = most_freq,
    sex = select_sex,
    from = from))
}

plot_top <- function(x, top = 10) {
  topx <- x$most_frequent$name[1:top]

  p <- x$babynames |>
    filter(name %in% topx, sex == x$sex, year > x$from) |>
    ggplot(aes(x = year, y = prop, color = name)) +
    geom_line() +
    scale_color_brewer(palette = "Paired") +
    theme_classic()

  return(p)
}



Here we call the code to visualize the top 10 most frequent girl names from 1950 onwards:
Plotting them for girls like this:

get_most_frequent(babynames, select_sex = "F") |>
  plot_top()







Figure 1: Line plot displaying proportion of top 10 girl names by year





In @fig-line-girls you can see that there has been a peak in popularity for ‘Lisa’, ‘Jennifer’ and ‘Jessica’. Interesting! Let’s have a look at the boys names:
Plotting them for boys like this:

get_most_frequent(babynames, select_sex = "M") |>
  plot_top()







Figure 2: Line plot displaying proportion of top 10 boy names by year





@fig-line-boys shows that names that were popular before 1990 are relatively infrequent after 2000.



# get most frequent girl names from 2010 onwards
from_year <- 2010
most_freq_girls <- get_most_frequent(babynames, select_sex = "F",
                                     from = from_year)

# plot top 5 girl names
most_freq_girls |>
  plot_top(top = 5)

# plot top 10 girl names
most_freq_girls |>
  plot_top(top = 10)

# get top 30 girl names in a matrix
# with names in rows and years in columns
prop_df <- babynames |> 
  filter(name %in% most_freq_girls$most_frequent$name[1:30] & sex == "F") |>
  filter(year >= from_year) |> 
  select(year, name, prop) |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = year,
              values_from = prop)

prop_mat <- as.matrix(prop_df[, 2:ncol(prop_df)])
rownames(prop_mat) <- prop_df$name

# create heatmap
pheatmap(prop_mat, cluster_cols = FALSE, scale = "row")











(a) Top 5











(b) Top 10













(c) Top 30







Figure 3: Most popular girl names from 2010 onwards

Plotting them for girls like this:

get_most_frequent(babynames, select_sex = "F") |>

# plot top 5 girl names
most_freq_girls |>
  plot_top(top = 5)

# plot top 10 girl names

# get top 30 girl names in a matrix
# with names in rows and years in columns

  filter(name %in% most_freq_girls$most_frequent$name[1:30] & sex == "F") |>
  filter(year >= from_year) |> 
  select(year, name, prop) |>

              values_from = prop)

rownames(prop_mat) <- prop_df$name

# create heatmap
